title: 109_hr1554
content: The Act is titled the "Christopher and Dana Reeve Quality of Life for Persons with Paralysis Act" and aims to improve the quality of life for individuals with paralysis and other physical disabilities. The Act, titled the "Christopher and Dana Reeve Quality of Life for Persons with Paralysis Act," authorizes the Secretary of Health and Human Services to study health challenges related to paralysis and physical disabilities. This includes developing a national action plan to enhance health, wellness, and quality of life for individuals with paralysis. The Act authorizes the Secretary of Health and Human Services to collaborate with voluntary health agencies on paralysis and physical disabilities. This includes supporting programs for care, rehabilitation, and quality of life, establishing a hospital-based registry, conducting research on motor disability, and developing comprehensive programs. The Act authorizes the development of innovative programs within State-based disability and health programs to support quality-of-life programs for individuals with paralysis and physical disabilities. This includes caregiver education, physical activity, education for healthcare providers, prevention of complications, home- and community-based interventions, coordination of services, and addressing the unique needs of underserved populations. The Secretary may award grants to State and local health agencies for establishing paralysis registries, developing action plans for physical disabilities, and creating partnerships to support individuals with paralysis and physical disabilities. The Secretary may award grants to organizations for coordinating paralysis and physical disability activities, providing education and training opportunities, and developing effective intervention programs. Nonprofit private health and disability organizations can use the grants for disseminating information, improving access to services, and testing model intervention programs. The Secretary shall ensure coordination of activities with other Public Health Service programs. A report on study results and a national plan may be submitted to Congress by December 1, 2007. $25,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2007 through 2010 for this purpose. The Congress emphasizes the importance of strategic planning at the National Institutes of Health to advance biomedical science. Collaboration among research institutes and centers is crucial for research on paralysis, improving rehabilitation, and enhancing the quality of life for individuals with physical disabilities.
